data.title: Ibrahim Nasir: first President of the Maldives
data.meta_description: Ibrahim Nasir steered the Indian Ocean island chain of the Maldives to independence from Britain in 1965 and became its first President three years later. For a decade he worked to guarantee future
data.text:
Ibrahim Nasir steered the Indian Ocean island chain of the Maldives to independence from Britain in 1965 and became its first President three years later. For a decade he worked to guarantee future prosperity by modernising the fishing industry and developing the infrastructure for tourism. However, his methods were authoritarian and, amid unproven allegations of corruption over the handling of public funds, he was obliged to resign the presidency in 1978.

Ibrahim Nasir was born in 1926, in Male, the capital of what was then the self-governing British protectorate of the Maldives, a chain of nearly 1,200 islands, most uninhabited. He had a privileged upbringing — his family were descended from one of the Maldivian royal families — and studied at a prestigious local school
